captions.text: Without a doubt,
the most exciting scientific observation of 2012
was the discovery of a new particle
at the CERN laboratory
that could be the Higgs boson,
a particle named after physicist Peter Higgs.
The Higgs Field is thought to give mass
to fundamental, subatomic particles
like the quarks
and leptons
that make up ordinary matter.
The Higgs bosons are wiggles in the field,
like the bump you see
when you twitch a rope.
But how does this field give mass to particles?
If this sounds confusing to you,
you're not alone.
In 1993, the British Science Minister
challenged physicists to invent a simple way
to understand all this Higgs stuff.
The prize was a bottle of quality champagne.
The winning explanation went something like this:
Suppose there's a large cocktail party
at the CERN laboratory
filled with particle physics researchers.
This crowd of physicists represents the Higgs field.
If a tax collector entered the party,
nobody would want to talk to them,
and they could very easily cross the room
to get to the bar.
The tax collector wouldn't interact with the crowd
in much the same way
that some particles don't interact with the Higgs field.
The particles that don't interact,
like photons for example,
are called massless.
Now, suppose that Peter Higgs entered the same room,
perhaps in search of a pint.
In this case, the physicists
will immediately crowd around Higgs
to discuss with him
their efforts to measure the properties
of his namesake boson.
Because he interacts strongly with the crowd,
Higgs will move slowly across the room.
Continuing our analogy,
Higgs has become a massive particle
through his interactions with the field.
So, if that's the Higgs field,
how does the Higgs boson fit into all of this?
Let's pretend our crowd of party goers
is uniformly spread across the room.
Now suppose someone pops their head in the door
to report a rumor of a discovery
at some distant, rival laboratory.
People near the door will hear the rumor,
but people far away won't,
so they'll move closer to the door to ask.
This will create a clump in the crowd.
As people have heard the rumor,
they will return to their original positions
to discuss its implications,
but people further away will then ask what's going on.
The result will be a clump in the crowd
that moves across the room.
This clump is analogous to the Higgs boson.
It is important to remember
that it is not that massive particles
interact more with the Higgs field.
In our analogy of the party,
all particles are equal until they enter the room.
Both Peter Higgs and the tax collector have zero mass.
It is the interaction with the crowd
that causes them to gain mass.
I'll say that again.
Mass comes from interactions with a field.
So, let's recap.
A particle gets more or less mass
depending on how it interacts with a field,
just like different people will move through the crowd
at different speeds depending on their popularity.
And the Higgs boson is just a clump in the field,
like a rumor crossing the room.
Of course, this analogy is just that --
an analogy,
but it's the best analogy
anyone has come up with so far.
So, that's it.
That's what the Higgs Field
and the Higgs boson is all about.
Continuing research will tell us if we found it,
and the reward will probably be more
than just a bottle of champagne.

title: The Higgs Field, explained - Don Lincoln

comments.text:
The Higgs field and its mediator, the Higgs boson, was first proposed in 
1962 by Philip Warren Anderson. The relativistic model was developed in 
1964 by three independent groups: by Robert Brout and François Englert; by 
Peter Higgs; and by Gerald Guralnik, C. R. Hagen, and Tom Kibble.

The existence of the Higgs boson was confirmed by the LHC to within five 
standard deviations in 2013, but the field itself and its associated 
particle was proposed 51 years ealier, though not by that name. The more 
complete theory was mainly developed two years later by Peter Higgs and his 
group, hence the name.
comments.author: Banter Maestro

comments.text:
I'm no expert, but I don't think it "increases" the mass of the particle so 
much as it gives mass to the particle.   Without the Higgs field, all 
particles would be without mass and move at the speed of light.  With the 
Higgs field, some particles gain rest mass and slow down, others don't (all 
particles have energy mass).    I'm not entirely sure E=MC^2 is the best 
way to think about it because Quantum Mechanics can do strange things, like 
travel backwards in time, or, apparently pull extra energy out of thin air 
and then return it a billionth of a second later.  

Also, because the Higgs field is everywhere, the mass is always there, from 
a practical point of view.  The Higgs field doesn't come and go, only the 
Boson.   Now, in a quantum sense, the mass might come and go with 
interactions with the Higgs Boson - I don't really know, but it would 
average out over time to be consistent. - if that makes any sense.

So, re-reading what you wrote, on the quantum level, it's possible that a 
particle's mass is converted from energy to rest mass by interaction with 
the Higgs Boson/Higgs field, but the net energy doesn't change only the 
form of the energy changes.    If that makes no sense, let me know.  I'm 
kinda trying to understand it myself.

The "clumping" of physicists that is shown in the video is the analogy to 
the Higgs-boson. It does not "organise" itself into quarks, but a 
Higgs-boson in reality can decay into them, much like a photon can decay 
into quarks.
The rumor in the analogy is a disturbance in the Higgs field. In reality 
one can i.e. excite the Higgs field at a point and this excitation will 
propagate through the field in the form of Higgs-bosons. How does one 
excite the field? A very nice way to do that is to take particles that 
interact with the Higgs-field and arrange a high energy collision in a way 
so you take the energy of the particles and convert it to an excitation of 
the Higgs-field (the Higgs-boson). This is also how it was discovered.

Photons are excitations of the electromagnetic field, just like glouns are

In actuality the zero mass of the photons is a result of the electro-weak 
symmetry breaking in the early universe. That is also the point about the 
Higgs mechanism. It's the simplest, Lorentz-invariant, gauge-invariant 
mechanism that could give the other three bosons that came out of that 
symmetry breaking (namely the Z, W+ and W-) their mass.
As such we can say precisely what came first ;)
comments.author: Schmidt975

comments.text:
It's the chicken or the egg.  Does a photon have zero mass because it does 
not interact with the Higgs field, or does it not interact with the Higgs 
field because it intrinsically does not have any mass (does not take up 
spacial grids in the space-time continuum)?  A photon is not made of 
typical elementary particles like a quark or gluon.  It simply is energy 
(both in wave an particle or quanta/photon forms).  Einstein taught us that 
E=MC^2.  Surely that means a photon of light has mass since energy IS 
mass???  No, the equation also works to be E^2=(MC^2)^2 + (pc)^2 where p = 
relativistic mass of the photon and c is the speed of light.  The first 
part of the equation is zero because mass at rest (m) is zero.  The second 
part (or specifically pc - or pv in normal terms) is momentum.  This 
equation means a photon of light has momentum but does not have a mass at 
rest.  Because of so, it does not interact with the Higgs field and 
therefore has no rest mass, which is the reason it travels at the speed it 
travels, in a vacuum.  Nothing with mass can reach the speed of light.

comments.text:
I like the Feynman quote.   I think, a "chess board" is a bit too simple 
though, as quantum mechanics and the standard model plays on something a 
bit more exotic than an 8 by 8 square, as you have charge, color, spin, and 
forces like gravity and charge as well as more exotic forces like the W and 
Z Bosons and the strong force.   It's a strange board, but I like the 
Feynman analogy all the same cause that's kind of how they figured this 
stuff out - they studied the stuff that came out of particle 
accelerators.   They measured how particles behaved and they learned and 
designed the model from watching the behavior.

That's how they figured out anti-matter.  They saw a particle that behaved 
just like a proton but it had the charge of an electron, and after seeing 
it enough times, they called it an anti-proton and the tests kept 
confirming it.

But I don't think what Feynman meant was that particles correspond to 
pieces on a chess board, what he meant was that studying how particles 
behave is like learning chess by watching it being played.

In some ways, Quantum Physics is predictable, like, they can predict how 
long it takes for an unstable particle to decay or they can predict what 
will happen when a proton comes near another proton (they will repel).   In 
other ways quantum physics is and will remain unpredictable like knowing 
exactly where an electron is and all that Heisenberg, Schrodinger or 
wave-partical duality stuff.    The Higgs Boston doesn't undo the 
uncertainty principal or the "god plays dice" aspects of quantum physics.

Theory states that as a elementary particle  approaches the speed of light

comments.text:
That is very incorrect. For once, the units don't work out. Mass is 
measured in kg. Action is measured in something like kg*m²/s.
Also: action is defined by the temporal Integral over the Lagrangian of one 
path. This means that a single particle can have different actions 
depending on which path they take.
Contrast that to the rest mass of an elementary particle: since the 
coupling to the Higgs-field does not change, the rest mass is always the 
same. This is why i.e. all electrons have precisely the same mass.
So no, mass is definately not equal to action!
And yes, you have very well noticed that a board game and a quantum field 
theoretical model of the universe are not the same :D

comments.author: Ramtin Shahryari

comments.text:
Yes and no. The Higgs field is what first gives mass to anything.  On the 
other hand, a photon of light has no mass at rest, so it travels at the 
speed of light.  It knows no other speed.  Objects with mass, as you push 
them towards the speed of light, the amount of energy you put in to 
accelerate an object, gets converted into mass via Einstein's famous 
E=mc^2.  It's not so much about the Higgs field, but more about E=mc^2. 
 This is the holy grail of equations, other than the theory of everything 
that unites all four forces of nature.  As the mass (called relativistic 
mass) increases from the energy given to it to push it towards the speed of 
light, the consequence is you now require even MORE energy to push the 
object even faster (since it's relativistic mass has become so large). 
 It's a vicious positive feedback loop.

comments.author: Mike Gecawicz

comments.text:
First, it's important to differentiate between mass and rest mass.    Since 
E=MC^2, any particle with energy has mass, but not all particles have rest 
mass.

So to answer your question as rest mass, all particles with the same rest 
mass would interact with the Higgs field the same amount.   Now, take 2 
particles with equal energy but different rest mass - say, an Electron and 
a Photon.   A Photon's energy depends on it's wavelength so it's possible 
for a Photon to have the same mass as an Electron (and remember, the speed 
of an Electron can add to it's mass as well).  But, where they interact 
with the Higgs field differently is due to rest mass not total mass.   In 
the video, they just call it "mass" but they mean rest mass.   

An Electron can't travel at the speed of light.   A photon can only travel 
at the speed of light.  An Electron interacts with Higgs field to create 
it's rest mass.  A photon passes through the higgs field un-slowed down, 
like the tax collector in the video.
comments.author: YTEdy

comments.text:
Chicken or the egg.  Is mass first, or is the Higgs field first?  Which one 
affects which?  Let's take this example: One object has like 6 quarks (a 
Hydrogen atom).  Another object has 12 quarks (a Helium atom).  The Helium 
atom, in the presence of the Higgs field, will have more mass because it 
has more quarks, the elementary particles that (make up protons and 
neutrons) interact with the Higgs field.   It's all about the total number 
of protons/neutrons, and a little of electrons (but electrons are super 
lightweight and do not contribute much).  In this truth, the two atoms do 
NOT have the same mass.  They may both be gases and you may contain them in 
the same sized balloon, but they are NOT the same mass, size or spacial 
displacement.

There is a fundamental misinterpretation when someone tells you that time 
is controlled by gravity. Time itself, is only an observation. By changing 
"time" you only change the reference of observation. Example, if you stare 
at a clock and then you start traveling at the speed of light away from the 
clock, the image you see shows the clock stopped in time. However, the 
clock is still ticking at the place of the clock. You only see the change 
of "light", not the change of time. In a world with 0 light, everything 
would still change.
